# MCMC

![DAG and local probability distributions](/Users/timvigers/GitHub/MS-Thesis/image001.png)

```{r mcmc test,cache=TRUE}
# MCMC parameters
n_adapt = 1000
iter = 50000
# Example nodes
methyl = "cg00339319"
metab = "gctof_33"
temp = pair_data[,c("T1Dgroup",methyl,metab)]
temp = temp[complete.cases(temp),]
# Data (X[,1] must be methylation and X[,2] must be metabolite)
y = as.numeric(temp$T1Dgroup) - 1
X = temp[,c(methyl,metab)]
N = nrow(X)
# JAGS
jags_data = list(y=y,X=X,N=N)
mod = jags.model("./code/networks/omics_to_t1d_methyl_to_metab.jags",
                 data = jags_data, n.adapt = n_adapt,n.chains = 2,quiet = T)
suppressWarnings(cat(readLines('./code/networks/omics_to_t1d_methyl_to_metab.jags'),
                     sep = '\n'))
# MCMC
samples = coda.samples(mod,n.iter = iter,thin = 20,
                       variable.names = c("beta0","beta1","beta2","gamma0","gamma1"))
# Bayes output
output = MCMCsummary(samples,Rhat = F,HPD = T,hpd_prob = 0.8)
MCMCtrace(samples,pdf = F,iter = iter - n_adapt)
```

# CIT Package

The CIT package is able to test two mediation structures with T1D status as the outcome:

```{r echo=FALSE}
plot(model2network(struct3))
plot(model2network(struct5))
```

CIT results from the same probe - metabolite pair as in the MCMC example above:

```{r cit test,echo=FALSE}
# cit
cinf = cit.bp(L = X[,1],G = X[,2],T = y)
colnames(cinf) = gsub("L","methyl",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("G","metab",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("T","T1D",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("assoc"," ~ ",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("gvn"," | ",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("ind"," indep. ",colnames(cinf))
kable(cinf,caption = "Single Permutation")
# Permutation tests
cinf = cit.bp(L = X[,1],G = X[,2],T = y,n.perm = 100)
colnames(cinf) = gsub("L","methyl",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("G","metab",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("T","T1D",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("assoc"," ~ ",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("gvn"," | ",colnames(cinf))
colnames(cinf) = gsub("ind"," indep. ",colnames(cinf))
invisible(lapply(names(cinf)[2:ncol(cinf)], function(x){
  hist(cinf[,x],main = paste("Histogram of",x))
}))
```

Distibution of p values looks reasonable (I think?) across permutations. The omnibus p value is elevated because it's simply the highest of the four others.

```{r cit on all,echo=FALSE,cache=TRUE}
cits = apply(pairs, 1, function(x){
  methyl = as.character(x["methyl"])
  metab = as.character(x["metab"])
  temp = pair_data[,c("T1Dgroup",methyl,metab)]
  temp = temp[complete.cases(temp),]
  y = as.numeric(temp$T1Dgroup) - 1
  X = temp[,c(methyl,metab)]
  cinf1 = cit.bp(L = X[,1],G = X[,2],T = y)
  cinf2 = cit.bp(L = X[,2],G = X[,1],T = y)
  p = min(cinf1$p_cit,cinf2$p_cit)
  d = which.min(c(cinf1$p_cit,cinf2$p_cit))
  d = ifelse(d == 1,">","<")
  if (p < 0.05) {return(paste(methyl,d,metab,p))} else {NA}
})
# Convert to dataframe
cits = as.data.frame(cits[!is.na(cits)])
cits = separate(cits,"cits[!is.na(cits)]",c("methyl","direction","metab","cit p"),
                sep = " ")
cits$`cit p` = round(as.numeric(cits$`cit p`),3)
cits = cits[order(cits$`cit p`),]
kable(cits[1:10,],caption = "Top Ten Pairs Based on CIT")
```

Using a threshold of p < 0.05 for the omnibus CIT test, there are `r nrow(unique(cits))` unique pairs with significant mediation. Within these pairs, there are `r length(unique(cits$methyl))` unique probes and `r length(unique(cits$metab))` unique metabolites.
